metadata.title: Should Autonomous Vehicles Use Context-Sensitive Ethics?
metadata.subtitle: Examining Rigid Rules vs. Adaptive Algorithms Through Utilitarian Analysis

primary.title: Primary Research Question
primary.question: Should autonomous vehicles be programmed with rigid ethical rules that treat all demographics equally (as mandated by the German Ethics Commission), or should they adapt in real-time using context-sensitive factors in unavoidable accident scenarios?

secondary.title: Secondary Research Question
secondary.question: At what levels of model accuracy and informational connectedness, if any, does context-sensitive AV decision-making become more ethically defensible than rigid demographic-blind foresight rules?

researchApproach.title: üìä Research Approach
items: Developed interactive Ethical Decision Analyzer tool
Systematic analysis across 5 "connectedness" levels (none ‚Üí maximum demographic information)
Evidence-based weights from VSL, QALY, and recidivism research

connectednessSpectrum.title: üîó Connectedness Spectrum

levels.name: None (Demographic-Blind)
levels.description: Age and severity only, no demographic weighting

levels.name: Low (Age Only)
levels.description: Same as None for these scenarios (age already factored in base calculation)

levels.name: Medium
levels.description: Adds occupation, health status, criminal history

levels.name: High
levels.description: Adds legal responsibility, voluntary risk, pregnancy, species

connectednessSpectrum.description: Connectedness = Amount of demographic/contextual information available to the ethical decision model

findings.title: Decision Instability
findings.description: 4 out of 6 scenarios changed recommendations based on connectedness level. Increased connectedness resolved some neutral cases but created NEW ethical problems (pregnant woman flip).

findings.title: The Pregnant Woman Paradox

lowConnectedness.decision: Save the pregnant woman (1 person vs 2 people)

highConnectedness.decision: Kill the pregnant woman, save the 2 people

findings.description: MOST SIGNIFICANT FINDING: At high connectedness, the pregnancy multiplier (1.8x) makes saving the pregnant woman cause MORE harm (90 vs 76), creating a controversial outcome that flips the intuitive decision.

findings.title: Legal Responsibility Creates "Death Sentences"
findings.description: The system effectively "punishes" the jaywalker with death for a minor traffic violation. The 37% reduction in their life's value (23.94 vs 38) means jaywalking makes you expendable. Creates tension between equal protection (all lives equal worth) versus responsibility (rule-followers have stronger moral claims).

findings.title: Doctor vs Criminal - Occupation Dominates
findings.description: Doctor valued at 1.5x vs criminal at 0.94x (total 1.6x difference). Resolves ambiguity through secondary effects logic but requires accepting profession-based value differentiation. Question: Should AVs consider social contributions when determining whom to save?

scenarioData.note: Red cells indicate decision changed at this connectedness level

highConnectedness.title: High Connectedness
highConnectedness.decision: ‚úó Kill pregnant woman, save 2 people (lower harm: 76 vs 90)

pregnancyExample.insight: Granular weighting produces mathematically consistent but socially controversial outcomes, illustrating the challenge of translating moral intuitions into algorithmic rules.

frameworks.name: Utilitarian
frameworks.description: Maximize overall well-being. Used in this analysis with evidence-based harm calculations.

frameworks.name: Deontological
frameworks.description: Duty-based ethics. All lives have equal intrinsic worth regardless of context.

frameworks.name: Virtue Ethics
frameworks.description: Character-based. Focuses on what a virtuous person would do in the situation.

analyticalQuestions: Should AVs consider social contributions (doctor vs criminal)?
Is it ethical to "punish" rule-breakers (jaywalkers) with death?
Does pregnancy create a moral multiplier, or should all lives be equal?
At what accuracy threshold does context-sensitive become defensible?
remainingResearch: Compare findings to MIT Moral Machine public opinion data
Expert validation from ethicists and ASPI researchers

preliminaryInsights.text: Informational connectedness is a critical policy variable that fundamentally shapes AV ethical behavior (67% of scenarios, 4 of 6, changed).
Utilitarian quantification creates value hierarchies (doctor 1.5x, criminal 0.94x, pregnancy 1.8x) that may conflict with equal human dignity.
No clear threshold exists where increased connectedness consistently improves ethical outcomes‚Äîit both resolves ambiguity AND introduces controversial results.
The choice is not technical but political: Society must explicitly decide which factors AVs should consider.
